* "Pulse, pulse, hit, pulse, sizzle, pulse, hit, sizzle"
* "Thump, thump, snap, thump, chirp, thump, snap, chirp"
* "Drive, drive, clap, drive, ping, drive, clap, ping"
* "Rave, rave, clack, rave, tic, rave, clack, tic"
* "Vibe, vibe, crack, vibe, tick, vibe, crack, tick"

These phrases try to match the rhythm and the sound of the words "Boom, boom, bang, boom, tick, boom, bang, tick" and at the same time they are related to electronic dance music by using words that are commonly used to describe the sounds of electronic music such as pulse, drive, rave, and vibe.

Please keep in mind that this is just a suggestion, you can always use your own creativity to come up with something that better suits you and your lesson.

Ok, the next one is Reggaeton:
(accent is accented hit)
[F^g]^g!accent!^gF ^g^g!accent![c^g]!ghost!c [F^g]^g!accent!^gF ^g^g!accent![c^g]!ghost!c |\ 
[F^g]^g!accent!^gF ^g^g!accent![c^g]!ghost!c [F^g]^g!accent!^gc [F^g]^g!accent!!open![c^g]2|]

This rhythm you've provided is an example of a pattern commonly used in reggaeton music. In this pattern, The score is divided into two measures, each measure contain 8 eight notes. The first measure has the following rhythm:

[F^g]^g!accent!^gF ^g^g!accent![c^g]!ghost!c [F^g]^g!accent!^gF ^g^g!accent![c^g]!ghost!c

The second measure has the following rhythm:

[F^g]^g!accent!^gF ^g^g!accent![c^g]!ghost!c [F^g]^g!accent!^gc [F^g]^g!accent!!open![c^g]2

The notation is asking to play the F note on the Kick drum, accentuated, then a closed Hi-Hat hit, accentuated, then a F note on the Kick drum, accentuated, then a closed Hi-Hat hit, accentuated, then a C note on the Snare, accentuated, and a ghost note, then F note on the Kick drum, accentuated, then a closed Hi-Hat hit, accentuated, then a C note on the Snare, accentuated, and a ghost note.

In the second measure, the notation is asking to play the F note on the Kick drum, accentuated, then a closed Hi-Hat hit, accentuated, then a C note on the Snare, accentuated, and a ghost note, then F note on the Kick
I forgot to mention open hi hat

I apologize for missing that detail in my previous response. Now that you've mentioned it, the rhythm you've provided is an example of a pattern commonly used in Reggaeton music. In this pattern, The score is divided into two measures, each measure contain 8 eight notes. The first measure has the following rhythm:

[F^g]^g!accent!^gF ^g^g!accent![c^g]!ghost!c [F^g]^g!accent!^gF ^g^g!accent![c^g]!ghost!c

The second measure has the following rhythm:

[F^g]^g!accent!^gF ^g^g!accent![c^g]!ghost!c [F^g]^g!accent!^gc [F^g]^g!accent!!open![c^g]2

The notation is asking to play the F note on the Kick drum, accentuated, then a closed Hi-Hat hit, accentuated, then a F note on the Kick drum, accentuated, then a closed Hi-Hat hit, accentuated, then a C note on the Snare, accentuated, and a ghost note, then F note on the Kick drum, accentuated, then a closed Hi-Hat hit, accentuated, then a C note on the Snare, accentuated, and a ghost note,

In the second measure, the notation is asking to play the F note on the Kick drum, accentuated, then a closed Hi-Hat hit, accentuated, then a C note on the Snare, accentuated, and a ghost note, then F note on the Kick drum, accentuated, then a open Hi-Hat hit, accentuated, then a C note on the Snare, accentuated.

This rhythm is a typical pattern used in Reggaeton music, and it is characterized by syncopation, accentuated hits and open hi-hat hits that give a sense of urgency and energy to the rhythm.
